body: @lm-konda says that It is better to create new branch `update-tf-version` in `blueoil/blueoil` repo instead of developer self forked repo, because updateing version needs many member collaborate.

Will we treat `update-tf-version` as develop branch? ü§î 
I think the development flow is following,
1. We fork `update-tf-version` branch and create the PR to merge into `update-tf-version` by each task for updating tensorflow. (may not need to pass tests)
2. After completing the development to upgrade, we will merge that branch into master.

Another selection, we can select directly pushing into `update-tf-version`.
What do you think? @ruimashita

@hadusam 's first plan seems more natural.
I think we should not push to `update-tf-version` branch directory.

agree with @iizukak the first plan at least isolates changes from each other :+1: 

it may break testing of the branch in meantime when it is still half updated, but it seems to be inevitable anyway

I'm sorry to turn the table up side down, but I'm using lmnet on TF 1.10 on my local environment, and it works fine for classification problems. Object detection requires a little modification, but it's not too difficult. (My modification doesn't work with TF 1.4, that's why I cannot make a pull request yet.)

Therefore, I think we don't need a "collaborative" branch in this case.

@tkng The problems occur when we use blueoil on docker. Native environment may be OK.

result with TF1.10.1 (classification)
```
-------------------------------------------------------------
root@DE10_NANO:~# ./lm_fpga.elf input.npy output.npy 
-------------------------------------------------------------
Comparison: Default network test  failed...
Failed count: 26
First failed report
index: 0 / 26
input: 0.000454384, expected: 0.000310403

-------------------------------------------------------------
```

@lm-konda, @tkng, @ruimashita  is my understanding right that, `input.npy` / `output.npy` comes from `lmnet`, thus the failing `./lm_fpga.elf` should mean that `dlk` does something wrong (supposing values itself are correct)?

In this case, we should be able to just built a reproduction using new tensorflow (pb + input + output), and file a bug on the compiler. Which could be investigated and fixed without any version changes at all... :thinking:

@n-nez supposing value itself is correct in this case (from tf-1.4's result).
I will attach two pb files. One is OK and another is NG.
